title: Cure Model Analysis Example
text: package allows easily build report cure mixture models. modeling functions wrappers smcure() function {smcure} package several functions available diagnose visualize cure model results.

title: Cure Model Analysis Example
text: using publicly available data 205 stage melanoma patients Department Plastic Surgery, University Hospital Odense, Denmark 1962 1977. original data available {ISwR} package (Dalgaard, 2008). version data available package cureit::melanoma Variables include: - ulc - ulceration status - thick - tumor thickness mm - sex - sex summary main available variables : calculate overall survival, consider death melanoma event. Patients died cause lost follow-censored. Disease death outcome data plotted summarized using {ggsurvfit} package {gtsummary}: Kaplan-meier curves can see disease death rate plateaus around .7, indicating patients may experience disease-realted death. patients experience event, may different way useful categorize. Cure models can help tease apart contribution clinical variables potentially heterogeneous sub cohorts.
code: melanoma %>%   select(tumor_thickness, sex, ulceration) %>%   tbl_summary() %>%   bold_labels() fit <- survfit(Surv(years, status) ~ 1, data = melanoma)  fit %>%    ggsurvfit::ggsurvfit() +    ylab("Disease-related Death Probability")+   xlab("Years") +    ylim(0, 1) +   theme_classic()

title: Cure Model Analysis Example
text: cureit() function wrapper smcure::smcure() allows code cure models using tidy framework. , fit model using ulceration status, sex tumor thickness variables interest cure survival portions. Note: can optionally provide different sets covariates survival portion cure portion:
code: fit <- cureit(surv_formula = Surv(days, status) ~ ulceration + sex + tumor_thickness,               cure_formula = ~ ulceration + sex + tumor_thickness, data = melanoma) p <- cureit(Surv(days, status) ~ ulceration + sex + tumor_thickness,   cure_formula = ~ ulceration + sex + tumor_thickness,   data = melanoma)  x <- predict(p, times = seq(100, 5000, 100), newdata = melanoma, brier = TRUE)  x$ tidy_mods <- tidy(fit)  tbl_regression(fit, tidy_fun = tidy.cureit) %>%    bold_labels()  tidy_df <- left_join(fit$tidy$df_cure, fit$tidy$df_surv)

title: Cure Model Analysis Example
code: nomogram.cureit(fit, time = 3)

title: Cure Model Analysis Example
text: calculate K C indicies model
code: library(ROCR)    mod_data <- mel %>%   mutate(sex = as.integer(as.factor(sex))-1)   mm <- model.matrix(~ulc + sex +                    thick_cat, data = mod_data)[, -1]  mod2 <- mod_data %>%   dplyr::select(days, status) %>%   cbind(mm)    k_fit <- evacure::smcure1(Surv(days, status) ~ ulcpresent +                              sex +                              `thick_catgreater 322` +                              `thick_catless equal 322`,       cureform = ~ ulcpresent +                              sex +                              `thick_catgreater 322` +                              `thick_catless equal 322`,       data = mod2,       model = "ph",       nboot = 200,       Var = T       ) k_index <- k_fit$eva["K"] c_index <- k_fit$eva["C"]   tribble(   ~"Statistic", ~"Value",    "k-index", k_index,    "c-index", c_index) %>%   mutate_if(is.numeric, ~round(.x, 3)) %>%   gt() %>%   gt::tab_options(table.font.size = "small",          data_row.padding = gt::px(1),         summary_row.padding = gt::px(1),          grand_summary_row.padding = gt::px(1),         footnotes.padding = gt::px(1),          source_notes.padding = gt::px(1),         row_group.padding = gt::px(1))

title: Cure Model Analysis Example
code: cureit(fit, prediction_time = 1000)

what: A package to build and evaluate cure models
title: A package to build and evaluate cure models
text: package allows easily fit report results cure mixture models using tidy framework. package includes functions : Fit mixture cure models Summarize coefficients using tidiers gtsummary Vizualize data using nomograms Assess model results Brier scores K-indicies

title: A package to build and evaluate cure models
text: can install {cureit} following code: Load package:
code: remotes::install_github("karissawhiting/cureit") library(cureit)

title: A package to build and evaluate cure models
text: Functions fit models wrappers smcure() function {smcure} package additional capability passing formula directly passing categortical variables without first creating model matrix:
code: p <- cureit(surv_formula = Surv(ttdeath, death) ~ age,    cure_formula = ~ age,    data = trial)  p$surv_coefs #> age, Survival model  #>        -0.001010027  p$cure_coefs #> (Intercept), Cure model         age, Cure model  #>             -0.32294763              0.01067634

what: Inference for Brier score for cureit objects — Brier_inference
title: Inference for Brier score for cureit objects — Brier_inference
text: Inference Brier score cureit objects

title: Inference for Brier score for cureit objects — Brier_inference
code: Brier_inference(object, newdata = NULL, nboot = 100, times, ...)

title: Inference for Brier score for cureit objects — Brier_inference
text: object cureit object. newdata base::data.frame() tibble::tibble() containing original predictors used create x. Defaults NULL. nboot Number bootstrap resamples generated. times Numeric vector times obtain survival probability estimates ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Inference for Brier score for cureit objects — Brier_inference
text: tibble

title: Inference for Brier score for cureit objects — Brier_inference
code: trial <- na.omit(trial) p <- cureit(   surv_formula = Surv(ttdeath, death) ~ age,   cure_formula = ~age,   data = trial )  times <- seq(5, 24, 0.5) bootbrier <- Brier_inference(p, times = times) plot(times, bootbrier$brier, type = "s", xlab = "Time", ylab = "Brier score") lines(times, bootbrier$brier_2.5, type = "s", lty = 2) lines(times, bootbrier$brier_97.5, type = "s", lty = 2) lines(times, bootbrier$brier_cox, type = "s", col = "red") lines(times, bootbrier$brier_cox_2.5, type = "s", lty = 2, col = "red") lines(times, bootbrier$brier_cox_97.5, type = "s", lty = 2, col = "red") legend("topleft", c("Cure model", "Cox model"), col = c("black", "red"), lty = 1)

title: Broom methods for cureit objects — broom_methods_cureit
text: x smcure object created smcure::smcure() exponentiate Logical indicating whether exponentiate coefficient estimates. Defaults FALSE. conf.int Logical indicating whether include confidence interval tidied output. Defaults FALSE. conf.level Level confidence interval. Default matches smcure(conf.level=) (typically, 0.95) ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Broom methods for cureit objects — broom_methods_cureit
text: tibble

title: Broom methods for cureit objects — broom_methods_cureit
code: cureit <- cureit(surv_formula = Surv(ttdeath, death) ~ marker, cure_formula = ~marker,  data = trial)  tidy(cureit) #> # A tibble: 3 × 5 #>   term                    estimate std.error statistic p.value #>   <chr>                      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 (Intercept), Cure model   0.293      0.147     2.00   0.0454 #> 2 marker, Cure model       -0.112      0.160    -0.703  0.482  #> 3 marker, Survival model    0.0132     0.113     0.117  0.907

title: Broom methods for smcure objects — broom_methods_smcure
code: smcure <- smcure::smcure(Surv(ttdeath, death) ~ marker, cureform = ~marker,  data = trial, model = "ph") #> Program is running..be patient... done. #> Call: #> smcure::smcure(formula = Surv(ttdeath, death) ~ marker, cureform = ~marker,  #>     data = trial, model = "ph") #>  #> Cure probability model: #>                Estimate Std.Error    Z value  Pr(>|Z|) #> (Intercept)  0.17534830 0.1665214  1.0530074 0.2923376 #> marker      -0.07737471 0.1823892 -0.4242287 0.6713991 #>  #>  #> Failure time distribution model: #>          Estimate Std.Error  Z value  Pr(>|Z|) #> marker 0.02216145 0.1249715 0.177332 0.8592476  tidy(smcure) #> $df_cure #> # A tibble: 2 × 5 #>   term                    estimate std.error statistic p.value #>   <chr>                      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 (Intercept), Cure model   0.175      0.167     1.05    0.292 #> 2 marker, Cure model       -0.0774     0.182    -0.424   0.671 #>  #> $df_surv #> # A tibble: 1 × 5 #>   term                   estimate std.error statistic p.value #>   <chr>                     <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 marker, Survival model   0.0222     0.125     0.177   0.859 #>

text: surv_formula formula Surv() LHS covariates RHS. cure_formula formula covariates cure fraction RHS data data frame conf.level confidence level. Default 0.95. nboot number bootstrap samples used inference. eps convergence criterion EM algorithm. ... passed methods object input object

Survival after malignant melanoma — melanoma
text: Data frame 205 rows 7 columns. contains clinical variables survival outcome data relating survival patients operation malignant melanoma. collected Odense University Hospital K.T. Drzewiecki originally sourced ISwR Package

title: Survival after malignant melanoma — melanoma
code: melanoma

title: Survival after malignant melanoma — melanoma
text: data frame contains following columns: id numeric vector, patient code. status numeric vector code, survival status; 1: dead melanoma, 0: alive dead cause. days numeric vector, observation time days. years numeric vector, observation time years. ulceration numeric vector code, ulceration; 1: present, 2: absent. tumor_thickness numeric vector, tumor thickness (1/100 mm). sex numeric vector code; 1: female, 2: male.

title: Nomogram for cureit objects — nomogram
text: Nomogram cureit objects

title: Nomogram for cureit objects — nomogram
code: nomogram(x, survival = TRUE, cure = TRUE, time = NULL, angle = 0, ...)

title: Nomogram for cureit objects — nomogram
text: x cureit object survival Logical indicating whether output nomogram based survival submodel. Defaults TRUE. cure Logical indicating whether output nomogram based cured probability submodel. Defaults TRUE. time Numeric vector times obtain survival probability estimates angle angle text labels ... Additional arguments passed methods.

title: Nomogram for cureit objects — nomogram
text: tibble

title: Nomogram for cureit objects — nomogram
code: c <- cureit(surv_formula = Surv(ttdeath, death) ~ age + grade,  cure_formula = ~ age + grade,  data = trial)  nomogram(x = c,time=300)

what: Predicted survival probability by cure model — predict.cureit
title: Predicted survival probability by cure model — predict.cureit
text: Predicted survival probability cure model

title: Predicted survival probability by cure model — predict.cureit
code: # S3 method for cureit predict(   object,   times = NULL,   probs = NULL,   newdata = NULL,   method = "prob",   brier = FALSE,   cox = FALSE,   ... )

title: Predicted survival probability by cure model — predict.cureit
text: object cureit object. times Numeric vector times obtain survival probability estimates probs Numeric vector quantiles obtain estimates newdata base::data.frame() tibble::tibble() containing original predictors used create x. Defaults NULL. method Output format predicted values: "lp" (linear predictor) "prob" (predicted probabilities). brier Boolean indicator calculating Brier scores specified times. cox Boolean indicator fitting Cox model training data calculating Brier scores specified times newdata. ... passed methods

title: Predicted survival probability by cure model — predict.cureit
text: named list prediction estimates

title: Predicted survival probability by cure model — predict.cureit
code: p <- cureit(surv_formula = Surv(ttdeath, death) ~ age,     cure_formula = ~ age,    data = trial)      pred <- predict(p, times = seq(5,24,0.5),  newdata = trial[complete.cases(trial), ], brier=TRUE,cox=TRUE)  plot(seq(5,24,0.5),pred$brier,type="S",pch=1) lines(seq(5,24,0.5),pred$brier_cox,type="S",col="red",pch=3) legend("topright",c("Cure model","Cox model"), col=c("black","red"),lty=1,pch=c(1,3))
